div.p: Greetings. Since Mr. Peter has not yet returned and has not written anything to you, dear brother, about the latest communications, I have nothing to write about the French affairs, about which there is now great silence. I hope well for the Lord's grace.
If, due to the arrival of certain German scholars at the court, no discussion has been held between them and ours, we expect Mr. Peter to return to us soon.
May the Lord guide his journey! The fury of the enemies of truth is so great that he can hardly return without danger; but he is safe enough who is under the protection of our Lord God.

If you have received any certain news about the Venetians, about Italy, about the Council of Trent, all of which you will investigate, please communicate diligently and promptly. Regarding Vergerio, I say this: I can hardly believe that he will come to Zurich; if he comes, he will be forced to listen to others as well, not to speak alone. You could easily understand what kind of person he is from his meetings and conversations.
I have never offended him, as far as I know; he began to neglect me for no reason. When I noticed this, I let him remain as he is, and I remain as I am.
I will say nothing now about his prince and Brentius; he is their servant. I suppose you have seen Brentius's book written against me. - The cause of the people of Claron has not yet settled.
I wish that under the ashes there is not hidden a fire, and indeed the fire of the Lord. Therefore, we must pray to the Lord to have mercy on us.

I would like to see Vergerio's booklet, I would return it after inspection. Greet the consuls, Gallicius, Pontasella, and other good men, especially Mr. Hercules von Salis, whose friendship I would like to gain through you; for I hear that he is a man of integrity in religion and otherwise also prudent, strong, and humane. Farewell.
Zurich, November 21, 1561. Also greet Mr. Friedrich von Salis.
Behold, while I write this, Mr. Martyr has happily arrived safe and sound and joyful.
I only greeted him; I asked whether the affairs of the gospel in France are going well; he replied very well. He was brought here by two captains, etc.

After eight days, more or sooner, if I can; for I have not yet conversed with him, etc. To the most excellent man Mr. Johannes Fabricius, minister of the church of Chur, esteemed lord and his dearest brother. Chur.
